ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 5 to 6
Spent 15-20 hours per week on reading/assignments for this class.
6 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The textbook was wonderful. The quizzes challenged me to read thoroughly and I'm glad that I did. I enjoyed class discussion very much. I learned a lot.
Enjoyed the scope of the course but did not always feel that the assignments were directly connected to the lectures

This was a small class (only 8 people) and at times, that was a little bit awkward, but most of the time, I enjoyed the smallness of the class and it encouraged me to participate more in discussions. The quizzes we had at the beginning of class were somewhat annoying, but honestly, they were a great motivator for getting the readings done! The structure of the course also was helpful in understanding the key concepts we needed to learn from the material instead of getting bogged down in all the details.
I felt this course gave a good overall basis of knowledge for developing country nutrient deficiencies and then overview of general regional and global policies around food.

Thecourse relies heavily on the readings assigned for each class meeting along with the quiz given during each session to reiterate the important material. The class covers the importance of so many biological nutrients I would have like to go into more of the biological pathway for each.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Debbie Lee Humphries  I think the instructor was very good. She is a good teacher, she cares about her students, and she puts a lot of effort into designing interesting and fun assignments. It's clear that the instructor is passionate about the topic, which makes learning from her a pleasure.

Instructor: Debbie Lee Humphries  Good lecturer; liked that the class was organized to interact with professor, TA and other students in different ways throughout the semester and within each class period

Instructor: Debbie Lee Humphries  Debbie is a very knowledgeable instructor and was very interested in meeting the needs of her students in relation to their academic interests and incorporating their previous experiences into the course material and assignments. She was also very open to feedback on the course and making necessary changes as we went along.
Instructor: Debbie Lee Humphries  She wants to have everyone succeed and cares what we are all interested in. She structures the class more as a discussion and expects everyone to interact.

Instructor: Debbie Lee Humphries  Debbie teaches this class with great passion and enthusiasm for the material. She taught the class in a small section format with daily handouts as the reference point for the discussion and new information.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Sarah Pallas was a very helpful and conscientious TA. She was quick to respond to questions and help whenever she could. I'm glad that I had the opportunity to learn from her.

Sarah Pallas is an excellent TA!She has a great breadth and depth of knowledge and is very helpful in answering questions and providing feedback about assignments. She was very responsive and added great insights to our class.
I felt Sara was very helpful and gave great input during class discussions.

Sarah brought great examples from her life experience in the field of global nutrition and overall insight. She helped stress important ideas and help us question policy approaches that have been taken to solve issues of global nutrition.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend the course. It provides both fact based materials and "food" for thought to take with you after the course.
Good intro to global nutrition issues

I would recommend this course to another student, with the caveat that it will not fit everyone's interests or course style preferences. The class is highly participation-based (which is a plus for me, but may not be for other people) and is very globally focused, with very little discussion on nutrition issues within the United States.
A worthwhile class for anyone who wants to get a better understanding of developing country nutrition and food issues.

A great introduction to nutrition issues and the major research studies done so far. The course is constructed around textbook readings assigned for each class meeting which talk about biological pathways, research studies and policy outcomes and implications.
